top_number_claims: We have adopted ISO 50001 Energy Management System (EMS) across our campuses, with three campuses (Kodathi, Chennai, and Sarjapur 2) receiving certifications in August 2022, covering 35% of our total operational office space.

GRI 302-4, 302-5Energy Efficiency
Our transition to renewable energy over the years has enabled us to move steadily towards our target to decarbonize our operations.
This includes 586 trillion Joules of purchased renewable electricity and 10 trillion Joules self-generated through solar PV, totaling approximately 754 trillion Joules of energy.
We have considered DEFRA 2024 version 1.1 and CEA conversion factors to calculate our energy consumption.
Notably, around 85% of our total global electricity (including all Indian and global sites) usage is concentrated in India, where our large operational centers are located.
During the financial year, the refrigerants used by our organization included R-134A, R-22, R-32, R-404A, R-407A, R-407B, R-407C, and R-410A.
This year, 89% of our facilities underwent assessment and have received ISO 14001 and ISO 45001 certification.
In FY25, we purchased around 116 trillion Joules of grid power and consumed another 40 trillion Joules of diesel-generated backup power.
For categories where 2024 factors are not available, we have referred to DEFRA 2021 and DEFRA 2017, along with other relevant and reliable sources.
Commuting time rose from 7% pre-pandemic to 15% in 2023* , driven by factors like metro construction and traffic congestion.

To assess the climate impact of these substances, 
we evaluated their Ozone Depletion Potential (ODP), which indicates the extent to which a substance can degrade the ozone layer compared to CFC-11.

In FY25, our total GHG emissions amounted to approximately 219,683 tCO
2e, 
out of which Scope 3 emissions accounted for around 86%, primarily driven by value chain activities.

Today, Wipro is powered by 84% purchased renewable electricity, helping reduce our contribution to atmospheric GHG emissions by 120,506 tCO
2e and 
avoid the potential addition of equivalent fossil-fuel capacity to the power grid.

Our Scope 1 emissions include carbon dioxide (CO
2) methane 
(CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O) and Hydrofluorocarbons 
(HFCs).

At Wipro, commute-related emissions surged, 
accounting for 40% of our Scope 3 footprint in FY25—a threefold increase from FY24.
Emissions intensity encompasses all sources of GHG emissions (Scope 1, 2, and 3) at the organizational level, specifically for sites under direct operational control in India.

GRI 303-2, 303-4
As per Wipro’s Water Policy , we ensure that 
no untreated wastewater is discharged into subsurface waters, surface waters, or sewers leading directly to rivers, oceans, lakes, wetlands, or groundwater.

*Since the TDS of water is less than 1,000mg/L, entire water 
withdrawn is considered under freshwater category.Our freshwater resources are sourced from 
third-party purchases and groundwater.
Our water sources are from proximate groundwater aquifers, municipal supply and private water tankers (Refer page 75).
In-situ groundwater constitutes approximately 1.24% of our total freshwater consumption across various cities in India.
Till date, we have procured around 22 megaliters of treated water.

Wipro targets over 98% waste recycling 
(excluding C&D) by 2030 and has reached 97% as of 2025.
* Other waste including C&D is 9,725 tons **Total waste including C&D is 13,541 tons.

GRI 306-2, 306-3
Wipro employs a centralized digital platform to record and manage waste data across all operational sites.

In FY25, we generated 13,541 tons of waste 
(including C&D), reflecting an enormous increase from the previous year, primarily driven by a 4-fold surge in C&D waste.
Estimating that IT-related commercial construction accounts for 10–15% of total urban commercial development, then the IT sector could be responsible for 15–22 million tons of C&D waste per year.
